Triggering Event: In the bustling kitchen of La Petite Maison, he chopped onions at his station, tears streaming down his face—not from the vegetables, but from the overwhelming chaos around him. Orders piled up like unpaid invoices, and no matter how fast he worked, the tickets kept coming. He felt his girlfriend's eyes on him through the pass, her usual warm smile replaced by a furrowed brow of concern. But there was no time to comfort her or himself; tonight, it seemed, even the ovens were conspiring against him, smoking and spitting like angry dragons. As he reached for yet another ticket, his arm brushed against the hot plate, searing his skin. He yanked his hand back, but the pain was nothing compared to the helplessness that surged through him as he watched his carefully crafted mise en place crumble into disorder.
Generated Assessment: He was so upset with the way things were going that I didn't even notice when he started chopping onions. It wasn't until someone mentioned that he was crying that I realized what was happening. I thought maybe he had just gotten really tired, so I offered to take over some of his tasks, but he refused, saying he could handle everything. When I asked if he needed help with anything else, he told me that he already had enough people working with him. I tried to reassure him that we'd get through this together, but he just shook my head and said he didn't need any more stress right now.

Triggering Event: She woke up to find her partner already gone, the coffee untouched and cold beside his phone, which displayed three missed calls from the hospital. Her stomach knotted as she hurriedly dressed, anxiety clawing at her chest like a familiar foe, whispering fears of emergencies, of mistakes. She reached for her own phone, hands trembling slightly, to dial into the automated system for messages.
Generated Assessment: She was so upset that she forgot about her day job and work. She spent the entire day in the hospital with him, even though he was fine. The doctors said he had a minor heart attack but no other serious issues. It was just a stress-related issue, something that could have happened anytime. When they got home, she was still shaken by the experience and decided to take some time off work to care for him. She didn’t realize how much time it would consume, especially since she’s been dealing with the aftermath of his father’s passing recently. After all, he needed her now more than ever, and she wouldn’t let anything get in the way. He couldn’t handle everything alone, not after what he’d been through. His dad had died suddenly, leaving them both reeling. But this wasn’t the first time her boyfriend had fainted—just last month, he’d collapsed in front of her, too. The doctors had said it was just a panic attack, nothing to worry about. Still, she felt guilty for not being there when he needed her most. They were supposed to go out together the next weekend, but instead, she stayed home to cook dinner and make sure he was comfortable. Maybe if I hadn’t left him alone for so long, maybe things wouldn’t have turned out like this. He’s back home now, resting, and everything feels normal again. But she can’t shake the memory of that moment, the fear gripping her tightly.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her empty house, she noticed his favorite chair had begun to collect dust. As she ran her fingers over its worn armrest, a single tear fell onto the fabric, leaving a dark stain that seemed to spread like ink. She sat down gently, as if he might still be there, and listened to the silence. The sorrow was heavy, but familiar now, like an old friend she could no longer ignore.

Those fake smiles are just a way to make me happy while he secretly plots against me. He's probably planning to leave me right now, to go back to his ex who loves him more than she loves me. Or maybe he's just waiting for me to forget about him and move on with my life. It's so easy to imagine what he's really thinking - how he hates me for leaving him behind. How he wishes I'd never left. How he wants me to come back and start over again. But then why does he keep sending me these little gifts? Maybe he's just trying to guilt trip me into coming back. That's all this means - guilt trips. He's manipulating me to stay with him because he can't handle living without me. But then why does he argue with me so much? Triggering Event: While rushing to catch her train, she noticed an unopened letter addressed to her husband in their shared mailbox, hidden beneath a pile of junk mail. The sender was his estranged mother, whom he hadn't spoken to in years due to a family feud.

It’s such a shame because they were meant to be together. They should have stayed married instead of letting things fall apart. But what really gets me is that she thinks she’s right. She knows nothing about my parents’ relationship and still insists on judging them. It’s infuriating to see her try to manipulate everyone into feeling sorry for her. She doesn’t even care about what we think! And don’t even get me started on how she’s trying to turn my mom against him. My dad already has enough stress from work; I don’t want my mom to add more pressure. But she won’t listen to reason, just like she didn’t listen during the divorce. Now she’s using guilt trips to get under my mom’s skin. It’s so frustrating to watch her ruin every situation. She’s never been a good influence, especially with our family. I’m so sick of her drama and manipulation. I wish she’d stop making things worse. Triggering Event: She found the note from the student tucked into her planner during lunch duty, "I hate you, Mrs. T." It stung, a harsh reminder of yesterday's heated words over a missed assignment. She felt the familiar gnaw of guilt and failure as she crumpled it into her pocket, her appetite fading.
Generated Assessment: Fuck, this is so awkward! I can't believe she actually thinks I'm some kind of monster, but why would she think that? We had such a great time together, and now this stupid note makes me feel like shit. What if she really hates me? Maybe I was too hard on her last week. I always try to be fair and understanding, but maybe I just don't get it. Does she even understand how much work goes into grading papers? Or am I just an asshole? It feels like she's out to get me, and this note is proof of that. But what about all those times we talked? Why does she keep acting like I'm some kind of monster? The more I think about it, the angrier I become. This isn't fair at all. I want to scream, but instead, I'm just sitting here feeling like a total idiot. I have no idea what I did wrong, but I'm starting to think she's just trying to get back at me for something else entirely. Maybe there's another teacher who made her mad somehow. This whole thing is making me sick with anxiety.

Triggering Event: Walking home from his late shift, he passes their old treehouse in the neighbor's yard. It's dark and rundown now, but his mind fills it with laughter and her smile. He remembers promising to repaint it together last summer. Regret weighs heavy on his chest as he realizes he never did.

Triggering Event: An old photograph falls out of a worn, forgotten album as she dusts her empty house. It's a picture of her ex-husband laughing at their wedding, his arm around her waist. She'd been the one to push for divorce, too consumed by her career to make time for them. Now, alone in their old home, she feels a pang of regret for what might have been.
Generated Assessment: Oh boy, I'm so glad that photo fell off the shelf today. I mean, it was just sitting there, waiting for me to notice, but I guess it wasn't meant to be seen. That guy was such an asshole anyway; he never even bothered to help with household chores. He was always working late nights while I stayed home with our kids. I don't know why he thought he could just leave like that, expecting us to keep everything together without him. What did we ever do wrong? Did you think you were better than everyone else just because you had a good job? When I found this old photo, I felt like I was hit by a ton of bricks. It made me realize how much my life had changed since then. But let’s be real, if he hadn’t left, none of this would’ve happened. He was probably just going through some midlife crisis. I bet he was miserable at work, stuck in some boring office job, feeling trapped. Who wouldn’t want to leave that? It sounds like he was just burning out from all those hours spent staring at screens. And honestly, I’m still mad about how he treated me when we were married. I remember how he’d always say things like, “You need to lighten up,” or “Stop being so dramatic.” Like, who does that? I was just trying to keep things together, but he didn’t care. He barely even helped with the laundry! Can you believe it?

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her small kitchen, she opens the worn recipe book her late husband gifted her decades ago. A dried rose falls from its pages, landing softly on the counter. She picks it up, tracing its delicate edges with trembling fingers. Her eyes well up as she remembers his warm smile, the scent of his aftershave lingering on the yellowed paper. She sets the rose aside and begins to cook, but her usual deft movements are slowed by a heavy heart. The familiar rhythm of chopping onions brings tears streaming down her cheeks, each droplet sizzling on the hot pan like tiny, salty explosions.

It’s a cruel joke, really—a game of chance where fate decides your destiny before you even know what it holds. Every step forward is met with two steps back, every breath filled with the weight of what could come next. And now, as she stands here, holding the wilted rose petal, she knows this truth all too well. In this moment, time itself seems to bend, stretching out every second into an eternity of pain. Each chop of the onion, each stir of the pot, feels like a betrayal—each action a reminder that nothing will ever be easy again. The kitchen, once a haven, has become a prison, trapping her in a cycle of sorrow that refuses to end. Even the simple act of cooking has turned into a torture, forcing her to relive memories that can never truly be lived again. But perhaps this is just the way it was meant to be. Maybe she was always destined to lose everything, to feel the crushing weight of loss that comes with loving too deeply. Perhaps the world doesn’t allow people like her, people who crave connection and meaning more than they care about survival. They’re always one misstep away from disaster, forever chasing something that may never be within reach. And yet, she presses on, driven by a stubborn hope that someday things might get better. Triggering Event: A faded photograph slipped from his old desk calendar, revealing an empty space where it had been held for decades. He picked it up, tracing the worn edges with a trembling finger. The image was of him and his late sister, laughing together in their childhood home. Today would have been her 58th birthday.
Generated Assessment: **Oh my god, I'm so fucking tired of seeing pictures like this!** They're just reminders that she's gone. **She'd always be there for me, but now she's nothing but memories.** It feels like she never existed at all. We were supposed to celebrate our birthdays together, but that day will never come. I remember how we used to laugh together, but even those happy times are tainted now. Her smile is all I see when I look at that photo. I can't shake the feeling that if I hadn't let her go, she'd still be here, smiling at me. But now she's just a memory. It doesn't make sense; I keep thinking about what could've been if I'd stayed longer. I feel so stupid for letting her slip away. She wasn't perfect, but she meant everything to me. Now she's gone, and all I have left is these old photos. I wish she was back, but life has to move forward somehow. I guess I'll just keep holding onto the past, hoping someday things will get better.

Triggering Event: She noticed the curtains twitching again, this time when she was alone in the house. Her partner, still at work, hadn't seen it. She could swear someone was watching her, but every time she turned to look, nothing moved. She felt a creeping unease, her heart pounding like it did on those late-night patrols years ago. The shadows seemed darker today, the silence louder. She picked up her phone, hesitated, then dialed the station. "Just checking in," she said, her voice steady despite the paranoia gnawing at her.
